message.content:
cs.GT, cs.IT, cs.SY, cs.MA, cs.LG

The paper applies a framework borrowed from economics to a problem in the smart grid, specifically the design of signaling schemes between a consumer and an electricity aggregator when they have non-aligned objectives. This suggests that the paper is likely to belong to the Game Theory (cs.GT) sub-category. Additionally, the paper establishes connections between the framework and the quantization problem, which suggests that it may also belong to the Information Theory (cs.IT) sub-category. The paper also deals with managing costs and optimizing power distribution, which suggests that it may belong to the Systems and Control (cs.SY) sub-category. The paper's use of a simple model to extract practical insights suggests that it may also belong to the Machine Learning (cs.MA) sub-category. Finally, the paper's focus on source and channel coding suggests that it may also belong to the Learning (cs.LG) sub-category.
